PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIA, JAPAN AND SOUTH KOREA STOCK NEWS: Macquaries earnings, AMP drops plan to sell NZ wealth management business, Fast Retailing same store sales fell 57%
content:
AUSTRALIA

AMP (AMP AT) - Co. drops plan to divest its New Zealand wealth management business due to COVID-19 disruptions. (Newswires)

Macquarie (MQG AT) - FY net AUD 2.73bln vs. Prev. AUD 2.98bln Y/Y, oper. rev. AUD 12.3bln vs. Prev. AUD 12.7bln Y/Y, declares final dividend AUD 1.80/shr and notes FY20 credit and other impairment charges rose to AUD 1.04bln from AUD 552mln Y/Y due to potential impact of coronavirus, Co. does not provide guidance. (Newswires)

Orica (ORI AT) - Co. Q1 net AUD 165.2mln vs. Prev. AUD 262.2mln Y/Y, lowers dividend. (Newswires)

Orora (ORA AT) - Co. announces reverse stock split of 0.8 shares per share, (Newswires

REA Group (REA AT) - Co. April national residential listings fell 33% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Telstra (TLS AT) - Co. writes down value of 35% stake in Foxtel to AUD 450mln from AUD 750mln. (Newswires)

Wesfarmers (WES AT) - Co. is said to be looking at 20 potential takeover targets. (AFR)

Other News - Australian Cabinet is expected to ease some of its social distancing restrictions and relax restrictions in 4-week stages. (SMH)

 

JAPAN

Fast Retailing (9983 JT) - Co. April same store sales fell 56.5% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Fujifilm Holdings (4901 JT) - Co. developed reagent for coronavirus testing in 75 minutes by eliminating step in lab process, while it is to begin selling PCR coronavirus testing kits in Japan this month. (Newswires)

Konica Minolta (4902 JT) - Co. awarded OCEPC contract for security cameras. (Newswires)

McDonald’s Holdings Japan (2702 JT) - Co. April same store sales rose 6.5% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Mizuho Financial Group (8411 JT) - Co. lowers FY net profit guidance to JPY 445bln from JPY 470bln, Co. will record reserves for possible losses on loans and affirms FY dividend. (Newswires)

Nissan (7201 JT) - Co. is extending production downtime for most US plants and is still evaluating the situation before setting a restart date. (Newswires)

Shionogi & Co. (4507 JT) - Co. is reported to be launching virus vaccine by fall 2021. (Nikkei)

Yamada Denki (9831 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 24.6bln vs. Prev. JPY 14.7bln Y/Y, does not provide guidance. (Newswires)

Yamaha Corp (7951 JT) - Co. lowers FY net rev. guidance to JPY 414.3bln from JPY 425.0bln. (Newswires)

State of Emergency - Japanese Economy Minister Nishimura said they could remove some regions from national state of emergency around May 14th as some prefectures have seen no new cases for a week. (Newswires)

Other News - Japan is reportedly proposing to cover 2/3rds of rent for small businesses for up to six months to help weather through the coronavirus pandemic. There were also separate reports that a Japan senior ruling party official said the government is to start a debate next week on a second supplementary budget. (Nikkei/Jiji)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Hyundai Department Store (069960 KS - Co. Q1 net KRW 16.2bln vs. Prev. KRW 76.3bln Q/Q. (Newswires)

Kangwon Land (035250 KS) - Co. reportedly will be gradually reopening its casino from May 8th. (Newswires)

LG Chem (051910 KS) - Co. launches probe into a fatal gas leak at its plant in India where at lease 11 were killed and 1,000 taken ill on Thursday. (Newswires)

SKC (011790 KS) - Co. Q1 net KRW 79.2bln vs. Prev. KRW 86.1bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Other News - US has reportedly asked South Korea to pay USD 1.3bln in shared defence costs. (Yonhap)

Geopolitics - South Korea reportedly tested a new ballistic missile with a longer range, according to reports citing sources. There were also separate reports that North Korea slammed South Korea for a recent military drill which it called grave provocation and a North Korean military representative reportedly commented that everything is now going back to the starting point before the north-south summit meeting in 2018 according to a twitter report. (Yonhap/Twitter)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

US President Trump said he wants to ease travel restrictions at an appropriate time and that it is possible the administration will come up with further economic measures to help the people. In related news, it was also reported that the White House is considering actions it could take to stimulate the economy without requiring legislation and considering a possible delay in tax filing deadline, as well as moratorium on new regulations. (Newswires/NBC)

White House task force has reportedly requested the CDC review its reopening guidelines. Elsewhere, Michigan Governor Whitmer is to announce on Thursday the reopening of the state's manufacturing sector, where companies will be told they can begin work at their plants from next week, according to sources. (Newswires)

US House Republican Leader McCarthy commented that Congress should, regarding the next COVID-19 bill, wait to see the impact of existing support. (Newswires)

French Finance Minister Le Maire expects around 400k businesses to re-open on May 11th. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson spokesperson said any easing of the COVID-19 guidelines next week will be very limited. (Newswires)

UK COVID-19 death toll rose to 30,615 (Prev. 30,076) which is an increase of 539 vs. yesterday's 649 increase. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

US and China trade chiefs are said to plan a phone conversation as soon as next week on progress in implementing the trade deal in which Chinese Vice Premier Liu He and USTR Lighthizer will partake. (Newswires)

China’s Finance Ministry said they will extend favourable VAT policies for small firms through to the end of 2020. (Newswires)

PBoC will lift limits on foreign institutional investors to further open up China's financial markets, according to Global Times Business Source. (Twitter)

China Global Times Editor Hu Xijin stated that China is seriously implementing phase one trade deal with its purchase of American soybeans up 210% in Q1, although the pandemic would inevitably influence the schedule of the deal. (Twitter)

Japan is reportedly proposing to cover 2/3rds of rent for small businesses for up to six months to help weather through the coronavirus pandemic. (Nikkei)

Japan senior ruling party official said the government is to start a debate next week on a second supplementary budget. (Jiji)

 

UK/EU

BoE kept Bank Rate at 0.1% as expected via unanimous decision, while total purchases were maintained at GBP 645bln (QE vote split 7-2, 2 preferring a increase of GBP 100bln) and it stated that existing monetary policy stance is appropriate. (Newswires)

BoE stated it stand ready to take further action as is necessary to support the economy and that the timeliest of indicators on UK demand have generally stabilised at very low levels.

Financial Stability Report stated that having conducted a desktop stress test, the FPC judges that the usable buffers of capital built up by banks are more than sufficient to absorb the losses under the MPR scenario and also, with the support of the Government’s lending guarantee schemes, to help the corporate sector finance its cash-flow deficit.

However, the Committee assesses that the balance of risks to the economic outlook lies to the downside and that UK GDP in its illustrative scenario falls by 14% in 2020 as a whole, while activity picks up materially in the latter part of 2020 and into 2021 after social distancing measures are relaxed although it does not reach its pre‑Covid level until the second half of 2021.

BoE Governor Bailey said we are not out of monetary policy tools and expects to continue to come up with appropriate responses. Bailey added that it remains appropriate that the bank continues with aggressive pace of asset purchases for the moment and will take stock of it, while he stated there will be another MPC meeting before we near completion of the QE programme and the lifting of lockdown measures will be material to the discussion about QE in June. Furthermore, Bailey commented the Central Bank could do more QE in June and does not rule out negative rates but stated that discussions have "a long way to go".

ECB's Lagarde said a second wave of the COVID-19 is among the top fears and suggested there is no sense for how badly the economy is being affected. (Newswires)

ECB's Makhlouf said the German Court ruling does not get in the way of ECB doing its job and that it will not impact ECB action, while he added the most severe ECB staff project of 12% GDP contraction should be basis for planning. (Newswires)

EU Commission said ESM use will not require macro adjustment programme and that the enhanced surveillance linked to the ESM use will only focus on funds being used for COVID-19 health care costs. Furthermore, the Commission added that use by countries will not involve ad hoc on-site missions from the Commission and that surveillance linked to ESM use ends as soon as the money is spent. (Newswires)

 

FX

Turkish FX regulator is banning FX trades for three foreign banks which are BNP Paribas (BNP FP), Citi Bank (C) and UBS (UBSG SW). (Newswires) 

 

GEOPOLITICS

US Senate failed to override the Trump veto of the resolution curtailing his Iran war-making ability. (Newswires)

South Korea reportedly tested a new ballistic missile with a longer range, according to reports citing sources. (Yonhap)

 

US

Fed's Harker (voter, hawk) said there could be robust growth in H2 if the US economy reopens in June and that banks should not issue large dividends at the moment, while he sees brutally painful Q2 and noted that factories could bounce back but damage to travel and hospitality could be long. Fed's Harker also stated that negative interest rates would not have an effect on the economy in this crisis and evidence on effectiveness of negative rates globally is mixed, while he suggested he has a high hurdle for it. (Newswires)

Fed's Kashkari (voter, dove) said the paycheck protection programme was supposed to be a couple-month bridge, but it may need to be extended. Kashkari had also commented that a bad jobs report tomorrow would understate the damage because many people are not looking for work and believes true unemployment rate is 23-24%, while he thinks a depression can be avoided although they are facing a long gradual recovery. (Newswires)

Fed's Barkin (non-voter, hawk) said the US is probably "right at" the trough of the economic downturn. Barkin added that negative rates have been tried in other places and there is nothing to make him think they are "worth a try" in the US, while he added that his hurdle for more Fed action is if the central bank would have a positive impact. (Newswires)

Fed's Bostic (non-voter, dove) said the Fed is in a "whatever it takes scenario" and will deploy whatever is in its arsenal. (Newswires)

Fed's Daly (non-voter, dove) said no one who she has talked to is expecting a V-shaped recovery and she is not concerned about deflation or too high inflation, while she added the Fed has many tools left available.(Newswires)

US Initial Jobless Claims w/e 3169k vs. Exp. 3000.0k (Prev. 3839.0k, Rev. 3846k). (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Equities firmed overnight; desks suggested that the upside may have been a result of ‘catch-up’ as Asia players returned from market holidays, as well as market-friendly China exports data. The rally got a boost around midday when Fed Funds futures began pricing negative rates in the US from December 2020, however, action once stalled after failing to vault the crucial 2,900; the negative ticks were given some impetus after headlines noted that the Senate had failed to override a Trump veto of the resolution limiting his abilities to declare a war on Iran, however, the timing may have been a coincidence, since crude didn’t catch a bid on the headline, which one would expect amid increasing geopolitical tensions. Costco Wholesale Corp. (COST) comparable SSS -4.7% in April. Liberty Global (LBTYA) and Telefonica (TEF) announced an agreement to merge its UK business to create a 50:50 JV. Zoom Video Communications (ZM) (Information Technology/Software) has reportedly been made accessible to teachers by the NYC education department after the DoE withdrew its ban on the app. Tesla (TSLA) has halted production at its Chinese factory. It is also worth noting CEO Musk will be appearing on the Joe Rogan podcast again; last time TSLA stock was hit after he smoked marijuana on the show. TSLA is also reportedly planning to restart production at its Fremont, California factory. Moderna (MRNA) is finalising the protocol for its Phase 3 study of its COVID-19 vaccine MRNA-1273 and is expected to begin in early summer in 2020. Elsewhere, NIH Dr. Fauci highlighted the vaccine candidate, as well as Oxford University’s, accompanied by comments he expects the US to have a vaccine as soon as January. Ulta Beauty (ULTA) and Kohl’s (KSS) are to reopen select stores across the US. SPX +1.2% at 2881, NDX +1.3% at 9102, DJIA +0.9% at 23,876.

The TPLEX was heavily bid on Thursday, reversing all of the losses incurred after Wednesday’s bazooka refunding announcement. The short-end was particularly sought, where Fed Funds futures began pricing US negative rates in December out. By settlement, 2s -5bps at 0.13%, 5s -8bps at 0.30%, 10s 9bps at 0.63%, 30s -10bps at 1.31%. The grind lower in yields got going as the US session got underway, having risen in APAC and early European trade. There was no new/immediate catalyst for the strength, although desks note the likelihood of participants seizing the rate back-up from Wednesday in anticipation that the Fed would not let the UST curve continue to steepen. Tomorrow’s weekly Fed purchases schedule will be key for gauging the Fed’s tolerance for curve steepening, where it has up to now been tapering its weekly purchases, albeit at a declining rate each week; Morgan Stanley’s analysts believe the two most likely scenarios are either a lowering to USD 30bln per week, or to be maintained at USD 40bln per week, which if the former, the bank expects a steepening of the curve amid the supply/demand dynamic becoming “unfavourable”, while the latter would see little reaction. The TPLEX also continued to rally in the face of record corporate issuance – IFR noted this week marked the third largest for supply ever – where over ten IG issuers came to the dollar market today, including CVX, which is still to announce the size and pricing of its announced seven-parter. US T-note futures (M0) settled 24 ticks higher at 139-09+.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - May 7th: Markets begin pricing negative US rates
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries up, Dollar down, Crude down.
  • REARVIEW: Market prices negative Fed Funds rate; US/China trade execs. to hold a call; 3.17mln weekly jobless claims; BoE stands put, whilst two members dissent for further QE.
  • COMING UP: Data: German Trade Balance, US & Canadian Labour Market Report. Events: RBA SOMP & Moody’s Reviewing Italy. Earnings: ING, Rheinmetall, Siemens.

MARKET WRAP

Equities firmed overnight; desks suggested that the upside may have been a result of ‘catch-up’ as Asia players returned from market holidays, as well as market-friendly China exports data. The rally got a boost around midday when Fed Funds futures began pricing negative rates in the US from December 2020, however, action once stalled after failing to vault the crucial 2,900; the negative ticks were given some impetus after headlines noted that the Senate had failed to override a Trump veto of the resolution limiting his abilities to declare a war on Iran, however, the timing may have been a coincidence, since crude didn’t catch a bid on the headline, which one would expect amid increasing geopolitical tensions.  In the Treasury complex, yesterday’s refunding-induced jump higher in yields was pared back, with some suggesting that the afternoon moves may have come following supportive remarks from ECB President Lagarde, which helped the FI complex; others noted that Japanese players had returned, and Wednesday’s rise in yields may have enticed buyers; others, meanwhile, suggested it may be technical in nature. Elsewhere, crude was lower, unable to cling to gains. The dollar ended a three-day run of higher closes, while gold jumped as real rates were squashed. The market was happy to look through weekly jobless claims data since the narrative has been so heavily discounted. Fedspeak was again repetitive, although we will be paying extra attention to commentary on negative rates in the days ahead, given the implications of market pricing; some desks suggest that the Fed will have to address negative rates very quickly or risk falling into a self-fulfilling dynamic, and having to implement aggressive, hawkish commentary down the road.

NORTH AMERICA

US/CHINA: This morning sources reports noted the two sides will conduct a phone call among top trade chiefs regarding the progress in implementing the Phase One trade deal. USTR Lighthizer and his Chinese counterpart Liu He will partake in the call, and this will be the first time the two sides hold discussions since January. The trade deal calls for the two negotiators to convene every six months, therefore this call will be taking place ahead of schedule. The call comes amid a backdrop of punchy rhetoric from the US who have threatened tariffs if the Phase One trade agreement is not met, a condition mentioned when the deal was signed. Overnight, the trade data saw trade with US continued to decline in Q1 with the total value of China US-trade -12.8%, while imports from the US fell 3%, and exports down 15.9%, Global Times highlighted. However, editor in Chief, Hu Xijin, later noted China is seriously implementing the Phase One deal with purchases of US soybeans +210% in Q1, although the pandemic would inevitably influence the schedule.

US STIMULUS: US President Trump noted it is possible the administration will come up with further economic measures to help the people, where earlier source reports noted the White House is considering actions it could take to stimulate the economy without requiring legislation, adding it is mulling a delay in the tax filing deadline to September 15th from July, or even back to December, NBC reported.

REOPENING: Nevada is set to reopen on May 15th, while the Michigan Governor is reportedly set to announce the reopening of its manufacturing sector starting from as early as next week. Elsewhere, stores are slowly starting to return with Kohl’s (KSS) starting to resume operations in 10 states from May 11th, Gap (GPS) set to reopen 800 stores from this weekend, while Macy’s (M), Best Buy (BBY) and Nordstrom (JWN) are also looking towards a reopening shortly. Analysts are keeping an eye on the positive linearity of the reopening and will be paying close attention to sales figures and guidance in comparison to pre-COVID levels.

CENTRAL BANKS

BOE: The BoE opted to stand pat on rates at the “effective lower bound” of 0.1%, as expected; the decision was unanimous. Bond purchases were also held at the current envelope of GBP 645bln (GBP 625bln Gilts, GBP 20bln corporates), however, policymakers were split 7-2 on this decision, with Haskell and Saunders pushing for a GBP 100bln increase. Heading into the announcement, ING noted that purchases remain below the current ceiling of GBP 645bln and will likely remain so for another two months; i.e the Bank need not rush into making a decision at this stage. This view was reflected in the MPC’s statement, with members noting that existing policy was “appropriate” but the Bank stood ready to “take further action as is necessary to support the economy”. Furthermore, in a follow-up interview, Governor Bailey noted that the Bank “could do more QE in June”. Interestingly, in the same interview, the Governor refused to rule out negative rates, but noted that “discussions have a long way to go”. In terms of the findings of the Monetary Policy Report, the MPC’s central scenario (predicated upon a gradual unwinding of lockdown measures by the end of Q3), policymakers look for GDP to contract by 14% this year before rebounding by 15% in 2021. More specifically, “activity picks up materially in the latter part of 2020 and into 2021 after social distancing measures are relaxed, although it does not reach its pre‑COVID level until the second half of 2021”. Some desks viewed this as a potential over-optimistic view for the UK’s economic outlook; ING does not expect the UK economy to recover lost ground until at least 2022, and perhaps later. Furthermore, little reference was made to the UK’s withdrawal from the EU; another likely headwind to the economy. Additionally, some eyebrows were raised over the 8% unemployment forecast for 2020 despite almost a quarter or the private working population being supported by the government’s working scheme, which is due to be curtailed at some point. Overall, the BoE did not feel compelled to act at this meeting, albeit an adjustment to the Bank’s QE remit seems likely. What comes thereafter remains to be seen, however, any further deterioration in the UK economy will likely lead to a revision to the current planning scenarios on Threadneedle St.

NORGES: Norges Bank defied consensus and cut rates by 25bp to a record low 0.0% in a unanimous decision, as well as announcing the provision of further F-loans; given the downbeat domestic outlook which has been exacerbated by the oil market turmoil. Going into the meeting expectations were almost unanimously in favour of the decision being unchanged given the 125bp worth of easing during the COVID-19 crisis taken prior to the 25bp cut. The surprise move lower prompted significant weakness in the NOK; however, this was somewhat short-lived as Governor Olsen’s meeting remarks highlighted that rates are expected to remain unchanged at this period for the horizon ahead. It’s worth noting, that in slight contrast to this, Olsen commented that NIRP is a possibility; albeit, a very unlikely one – which isn’t too surprising given the well know reservations amongst the Norges Bank’s Governing Council to negative rates. Within the Monetary Policy Update, it was revealed that the Bank has undertaken NOK 3.5bln worth of extraordinary NOK purchases in the month of March – no details on April – to support proper market function; also, emphasising that they have no perception on EUR/NOK itself. Looking ahead, two sets of alternative forecasts have been released due to the unusually high levels of uncertainty the first ‘Alternative 1’ is based on the assumption that activity rapidly picks up faster than the baseline forecasts and sees rates gradually increase at the end of the projection period. While ‘Alternative 2’ is predicated on the domestic downturn being deeper and longer than the baseline, and sees rates at ‘close to zero’ throughout the projection timeframe; even with substantial fiscal support.

BCB: The Brazilian central bank cut rates by 75bps, taking the Selic rate to 3.00%; the move was deeper than the analyst consensus (-50bps) and money market pricing (around -60bps). The central bank said that the COVID-19 impact was deeper than expected. It also considered a rate cut for its next meeting that would not exceed this month’s move (75bps), with the argument of how much to lower the Selic hinging on fiscal policy and reforms. “We expect the curve to bull steepen as the market prices in the terminal rate to be 2.25-2.50% in line with BCB’s guidance,” Morgan Stanley said, “in addition, we also anticipate front-end DI outperformance as markets price in lower rates for longer, especially as two members explicitly suggested the introduction of forward guidance to enhance the stimulus.” In terms of the impact for the currency, MS expects BRL to continuing underperforming as the BCB pushes monetary policy to its limits.

ECB President Lagarde said the ECB is accountable to the European Parliament and are driven by its mandate alone – coming amid the ramp up of tension between German policymakers and the central bank.

FIXED INCOME

US T-NOTE FUTURES (M0) SETTLED 24 TICKS HIGHER AT 139-09+.

The TPLEX was heavily bid on Thursday, reversing all of the losses incurred after Wednesday’s bazooka refunding announcement. The short-end was particularly sought, where Fed Funds futures began pricing US negative rates in December out. By settlement, 2s -5bps at 0.13%, 5s -8bps at 0.30%, 10s 9bps at 0.63%, 30s -10bps at 1.31%. The grind lower in yields got going as the US session got underway, having risen in APAC and early European trade. There was no new/immediate catalyst for the strength, although desks note the likelihood of participants seizing the rate back-up from Wednesday in anticipation that the Fed would not let the UST curve continue to steepen. Tomorrow’s weekly Fed purchases schedule will be key for gauging the Fed’s tolerance for curve steepening, where it has up to now been tapering its weekly purchases, albeit at a declining rate each week; Morgan Stanley’s analysts believe the two most likely scenarios are either a lowering to USD 30bln per week, or to be maintained at USD 40bln per week, which if the former, the bank expects a steepening of the curve amid the supply/demand dynamic becoming “unfavourable”, while the latter would see little reaction. The TPLEX also continued to rally in the face of record corporate issuance – IFR noted this week marked the third largest for supply ever – where over ten IG issuers came to the dollar market today, including CVX, which is still to announce the size and pricing of its announced seven-parter.

NEGATIVE RATES: the speculation around negative interest rates in the US grew louder today as Fed Funds futures, at the turn of the year maturities, rose above par, while the same time 2-year yields made all-time lows too, and still continues to print new lows below 13bps. The Fed has previously stated its strong aversion to negative rates (Fed Chair Powell noted the current target range as the ‘effective lower bound’), although some draw attention to (non-voter) Bostic’s comments today that all tools remain available for the Fed and that it is in a “whatever it takes” mode. Signalling from the Fed will become even more crucial, where if it does indeed want to stamp out any expectation of a negative FFR, it will need to make that clear to the market; BMO’s strategists to wit, “...if the FOMC drags their feet too much, they run the risk of creating either a self fulfilling dynamic and/or having to effectively implement ‘hawkish’ Fedspeak later down the road.” Note that Fed’s Barkin (non-voter) said later that negative rates have been tried in other place but there is nothing to make him think they are worth a try in the US.

CRUDE

WTI (M0) SETTLES USD 0.44 LOWER AT USD 23.55; WTI (N0) SETTLES USD 0.79 LOWER AT USD 24.83; BRENT (N0) SETTLES USD 0.26 LOWER AT USD 29.46

Oil had a choppy session after it made strong gains overnight and in the European session to then retreat towards settlement. Futures had found some support from the Chinese trade data, which showed the world’s largest crude buyer’s imports in April rose by 1.7% from their March levels to 9.88mln BPD; Citi highlights that although it was an increase, the Y/Y figure is still down by 7.5%, “As with other data, the market currently seems to prefer a more optimistic interpretation, preferring to view the glass as 25% full rather than 75% empty.” Elsewhere, Saudi Aramco raised its June Arab Light Official Selling Prices to Asia by USD 1.40 to USD -5.90 vs Oman/Dubai average (Prev. USD -7.30); NW Europe at USD -3.70 vs ICE Brent (Prev. USD -10.25); US at USD +0.75 vs ASCI (Prev. -0.75). Equinor’s CEO said he does not believe in a quick rebound in the oil market and that it could take until 2022 to see markets normalise, noting that deeper cuts would improve the situation.

DATA

NFP PREVIEW: The April jobs report is due for release at 0830 ET/1330 BST on Friday; the consensus looks for -22mln and for the unemployment rate to spike to 16.0%; our full preview can be accessed here.

JOBLESS CLAIMS: Weekly initial jobless claims data printed 3.17mln, higher than the 3mln consensus; the prior was revised up slightly to 3.85mln -- the cumulative total since mid-March is now around 33.5mln. Continuing claims, meanwhile, jumped to 22.65mln, above the 19.91mln forecast, while the prior was revised higher -- that 22.65mln is around three times greater than the peak in the great recession. Oxford Economics said that while initial claims continue to slowly recede from their peaks (this was the fifth straight week lower), they remain at painfully high levels - claims at 3.17mln are around 15 times the level of claims before the pandemic, OxEco notes, and the consultancy sees continuing claims numbers continuing to rise given it lags initial claims. Others have noted that weekly claims are decaying at rate of around 15-18% per week, and if the current trajectory continues, claims will be sub-1mln in the second or third week of June.

EQUITIES

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +1.2% at 2881, NDX +1.3% at 9102, DJIA +0.9% at 23,876

SECTORS: Energy +2.5%, Financials +2.2%, Materials +2.1%, IT +1.5%, Discretionary +1.3%, Industrials +1.1%, Real Estate +0.9%, Communicatons +0.6%, Utilities +0.4%, Health Care -0.1%, Staples -0.4%

STOCK SPECIFICS: Costco Wholesale Corp. (COST) comparable SSS -4.7% in April. Liberty Global (LBTYA) and Telefonica (TEF) announced an agreement to merge its UK business to create a 50:50 JV. Zoom Video Communications (ZM) (Information Technology/Software) has reportedly been made accessible to teachers by the NYC education department after the DoE withdrew its ban on the app. Tesla (TSLA) has halted production at its Chinese factory. It is also worth noting CEO Musk will be appearing on the Joe Rogan podcast again; last time TSLA stock was hit after he smoked marijuana on the show. TSLA is also reportedly planning to restart production at its Fremont, California factory. Moderna (MRNA) is finalising the protocol for its Phase 3 study of its COVID-19 vaccine MRNA-1273 and is expected to begin in early summer in 2020. Elsewhere, NIH Dr. Fauci highlighted the vaccine candidate, as well as Oxford University’s, accompanied by comments he expects the US to have a vaccine as soon as January. Ulta Beauty (ULTA) and Kohl’s (KSS) are to reopen select stores across the US.

EARNINGS: T-Mobile (TMUS) beat on EPS, missed on revenue, ARPU fared better than expected although net subscriber additions missed expectations. Raytheon Technologies (RTX) beat on both EPS and revenue. Paypal (PYPL) missed on EPS and revenue while it forecasts Q2 Adj. EPS growth of 15-20% and revenue growth of 13%. Hilton (HLT) beat on EPS and revenue; noted systemwide comparable RevPAR -22.6%. Lyft (LYFT) saw an EPS miss, although revenue was better than expected, it also announced it is planning to cut costs by USD 300mln by the end of the year.

JPM EARNINGS TRACKER: The bank notes that 66% of S&P500 companies have topped EPS estimates, with overall EPS growth improving since the start of the season (now -9% Y/Y); however, the bank says that earnings beats have not picked up, with the percentage of companies beating EPS estimates still at 10-year lows. In terms of sectors, Materials, Discretionary and Financials are showing double-digit negative EPS growth. Meanwhile, revenue growth is more or less flat.

EUROPE

EU COMMISSION said that ESM use will not require a macro adjustment programme. The Commission said that enhanced surveillance linked to the ESM use will only focus on funds being used for COVID-19 health care costs, and that use by countries will not involve ad hoc on-site missions from the Commission. Furthermore, surveillance linked to ESM use would end as soon as the money has been spent. The announcement appears to make it more politically palatable for countries to utilise the ESM, such as Italy, which has raised issues with the potential conditions alongside it, which opponents fear could be too arduous.

FOREX

DXY snaps three-day run of gains, while XAU spikes as markets start pricing US negative rates

USD: The buck’s rally has hit a wall, and looks likely to snap a three day run of higher closes, amid an improved risk sentiment after China trade data overnight, and reports that senior US/China trade officials have scheduled a call for next week. DXY managed to hold 100.00 in morning trade, however as the session progressed, downside continued as Fed Funds Futures for 2021 began pricing negative rates, dragging DXY sub-100.00. Despite constructive risk sentiment (equities higher, cyclical FX firmer) Treasury yields were lower, likely hampering the dollar, albeit this week still has seen decent appreciation in yields. Once again data had little impact as participants look towards the reopening the economy and medical updates.

JPY: Unlike in previous sessions, the Yen seemingly tracked risk appetite today while USDJPY bounced off support at the 106.00 level. It is worth noting Japanese players have returned from Golden week, although JPM believes activity will not return to normal until next week, therefore, next week could see a bit more volatility. JPMorgan also highlights the 106.00/10 support once again (which held very well overnight) with 105.15/25 beneath the key figure. On the upside, 106.35/40 is interim resistance.

EUR: The single currency reclaimed 1.08 to the upside against the greenback while EURJPY also found some reprieve amid a EUR rebound and JPY weakness, and is now back above the 3-year low which was printed yesterday. The single currency also will likely find some solace in the EU commission, which said the use of the ESM will not require a macro adjustment programme and the use by countries will not involve ad hoc on site missions from the Commission, so seemingly making use of the ESM more accessible for those who wish to use the funding, and potentially removing some of the stigma; it does not appear US players have reacted to the news with any conviction, so it is worth paying attention when the Europeans arrive on Friday (UK is away for bank holiday), and worth keeping an eye on BTP yields in Italy.

XAU: The precious metal is seeing solid gains today despite fairly constructive risk sentiment. The yellow metal is back above the USD 1,700/oz mark from USD 1685/oz at the intraday lows. The rally occurred while Fed Funds Futures in 2021 begun to price in negative rates, as real yields came in, which tends to be supportive for gold; and also as Treasury yields fall across the curve, paring back some of yesterday’s upside/steepening (see here), while USD weakness is also a traditional supporting factor. RBC yesterday revised its price target cases for gold, noting elevated gold prices are here to stay for now. RBC’s base case sees gold rising to USD 1,788/oz in 2020, and then USD 1,893/oz in 2021. RBC believes gold can continue to win if equities continue to improve as investors are acutely aware of the risks taken and will look for hedges in gold. It also says that low nominal real rates and eased monetary conditions will likely keep gold elevated, and the rate correlation to gold will reassert itself.

CYCLICALS (GBP, AUD, CAD): With equities firmer risk sensitive currencies are performing well, particularly AUD, NZD and CAD.

GBP however is still firmer but lacklustre in comparison. The BoE rate decision saw sterling strength as some bets for an expansion of QE were unwound, however, two policymakers did opt for an expansion at this meeting while Governor Bailey signalled an expansion of QE could come as early as June, likely capping any GBP upside. Bailey also did not slam the door shut on the idea of negative rates, although he intimated it wasn’t likely to be seen in the short term.

AUD the G10 outperformer buoyed by risk sentiment while overnight data showed the highest ever monthly surplus in March, blitzing expectations. The trade data is likely to support Q1 GDP data, analysts said. Citi, however, thinks that AUD remains overvalued, and if the currency “starts to dribble off”, its Sydney desk sees AUD eying a break below the recent range low around 0.6370, potentially targeting a move on to 62 handle before the week closes out. AUD also likely caught a tailwind from solid China trade data given the strong ties between the two.

CAD gains also benefiting from risk sentiment but more so from the early gains in oil, although oil gains had pared but the CAD strength did not. Ivey PMI saw little reaction to the Looney. Scotia highlights “with broader market volatility contained and crude oil picking up, we think the CAD should be able to pick up a bit more support in the near term at least even if broader range trading around 1.40 persists for now.”

EMFX:  EMFX was mixed, the majority were firmer against a falling greenback although BRL failed to take suit given the deeper than expected 75bps cut from the BCB last night while leaving the door open for further easing, but perhaps not another 75bps cut. Elsewhere, EMFX was firmer with decent appreciation in TRY and MXN, with the latter benefitting from firmer oil prices while its inflation was slightly firmer than expected although headline inflation still printed -1%. The lira saw heavy support after a Turkish FX regulator banned FX trades from three foreign banks after local reports noted the recent weakness was an attack organised by banks while Turkey recently expanded its FX manipulation definition. RUB was also firmer but off highs as the currency tracked oil prices as oil off highs.

Exxon (XOM) Baton Rouge, Louisiana refinery (500k BPD) restarting its small crude unit, according to sources
TREASURY WRAP: US T-Note futures (M0) settle 24 ticks higher at 139-09+
analysis_details:
The TPLEX was heavily bid on Thursday, reversing all of the losses incurred after Wednesday’s bazooka refunding announcement. The short-end was particularly sought, where Fed Funds futures began pricing US negative rates in December out. By settlement, 2s -5bps at 0.13%, 5s -8bps at 0.30%, 10s 9bps at 0.63%, 30s -10bps at 1.31%. The grind lower in yields got going as the US session got underway, having risen in APAC and early European trade. There was no new/immediate catalyst for the strength, although desks note the likelihood of participants seizing the rate back-up from Wednesday in anticipation that the Fed would not let the UST curve continue to steepen. Tomorrow’s weekly Fed purchases schedule will be key for gauging the Fed’s tolerance for curve steepening, where it has up to now been tapering its weekly purchases, albeit at a declining rate each week; Morgan Stanley’s analysts believe the two most likely scenarios are either a lowering to USD 30bln per week, or to be maintained at USD 40bln per week, which if the former, the bank expects a steepening of the curve amid the supply/demand dynamic becoming “unfavourable”, while the latter would see little reaction. The TPLEX also continued to rally in the face of record corporate issuance – IFR noted this week marked the third largest for supply ever – where over ten IG issuers came to the dollar market today, including CVX, which is still to announce the size and pricing of its announced seven-parter.

NEGATIVE RATES: the speculation around negative interest rates in the US grew louder today as Fed Funds futures, at the turn of the year maturities, rose above par, while the same time 2-year yields made all-time lows too, and still continues to print new lows below 13bps. The Fed has previously stated its strong aversion to negative rates (Fed Chair Powell noted the current target range as the ‘effective lower bound’), although some draw attention to (non-voter) Bostic’s comments today that all tools remain available for the Fed and that it is in a “whatever it takes” mode. Signalling from the Fed will become even more crucial, where if it does indeed want to stamp out any expectation of a negative FFR, it will need to make that clear to the market; BMO’s strategists to wit, “...if the FOMC drags their feet too much, they run the risk of creating either a self fulfilling dynamic and/or having to effectively implement ‘hawkish’ Fedspeak later down the road.” Note that Fed’s Barkin (non-voter) said later that negative rates have been tried in other place but there is nothing to make him think they are worth a try in the US.

PRICE ACTION: 2-year yields fall to fresh record low; Fed Funds Jan 2021 priced negative rates
analysis_details:
• Nothing specifically crossing the wires; the curve has been paring back some of the rise in yields seen after yesterday’s bumper Treasury refunding announcement.
  • Some note that this may be a function of paring back extreme moves seen on Wednesday, while some also attribute the buying to supportive remarks from ECB’s Lagarde. Another key possibility is the return of Japanese players after their market holidays – higher yields might have prompted buying at those levels.
  • In terms of the shape of the curve, 2s5s and 2s10s are now a touch flatter on the day, while 5s10s, 5s30s, 10s30s are still steeper (just). This may also be due to the lack of 4-year or 6-year tenors announced by the Treasury on Wednesday, some strategists suggest.
  • 10-year key levels remain the same: 0.3180% (Mar lo), 0.5430% (Apr lo), 0.60-0.65%, 0.7850% (Apr hi).
  • 2s10s key levels: 35-55bps (note the March high of 77bps).

subject: EUROPEAN PRELIMINARY CASH EQUITY CLOSES: EURO STOXX 50 (+1.25%) at 2879, FTSE 100 (+1.4%) at 5936, DAX (+1.4%) at 10,757, CAC 40 (+1.5%) at 4501, IBEX 35 (+0.95%) at 6735, FTSE MIB (+0.5%) at 17,247, SMI (+0.5%) at 9623
Daily FX Wrap: currency markets think it’s good for US and China to talk trade
content:
GBP/JPY/EUR

Only a temporary relief rally for the Pound after the BoE maintained rates at the lower bound and opted against any increase in QE as preferred by 2 of the 9 MPC members, with Governor Bailey subsequently remarking in post-presser media commentary that the door is open for asset purchases to be raised further in June. Cable knee-jerked from the low 1.2300 area to just over 1.2400, but failed to sustain short covering momentum as the Dollar remained firm independently and garnering impetus from the demise of others, like the Yen that could not breach 106.00 before the re-open of Japanese markets following Golden Week. On that note, Usd/Jpy has now rebounded through 106.50 where 1.1 bn option expiries ran off, with the DXY largely undaunted by the latest multi-million US initial claims tally on its way to a new post-month end/early May high at 100.4000. Back to Sterling, 1.2300 vs the Greenback has given way to leave April 21’s 1.2248 low exposed and Eur/Gbp is edging towards 0.8800 even though the single currency has slipped a bit deeper below 1.0800 against the Buck amidst more evidence of Eurozone economic fallout from COVID-19 and ECB President Lagarde underlining the GC’s determination to implement its PSPP (and PEPP by the same token) regardless of GCC challenges on the grounds of proportionality.

CAD/AUD/NZD

All benefiting from renewed risk appetite, initially prompted by rises in Chinese and Aussie exports boosting respective trade surpluses, and then supplemented by reports that high level trade talks between the US and China are scheduled to take place by phone next week. The Loonie also got a lift from crude prices resuming their rebound, with Saudi Aramco lifting Arab Light OSPs, to the extent that Usd/Cad is back within striking distance of 1.4000 even though Canadian Ivey PMIs fell again, while Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd are both holding the bulk of their gains near 0.6450 and 0.6040 respectively.

CHF/NOK

Contrasting sessions for the Swiss Franc and Norwegian Crown, as Usd/Chf climbed beyond 0.9750 and Eur/Chf bottomed at 1.0525 after a marked increase in SNB FX reserves, but Eur/Nok pared post-Norges Bank gains to get even closer to the psychological 11.0000 mark. To recap, the benchmark depo rate was cut to zero from 0.25% against consensus for no change and F-loans were extended from end May to end August, but Governor Olsen implied no more easing even though NIRP is not ruled out in line with the rate path.

EM

At last some joy if not quite delight for the Try, but only after drastic measures from Turkey’s banking authority banning 3 foreign banks from trading FX, as the Lira recovers from new record lows near 7.2700, but the baton passed to the Brl after the BCB decided to lower the Selic rate by 75 bp vs -1/2 point consensus late yesterday and the Czk also had to contend with the CNB matching the move to 0.25% from 1%. Real nursing some losses from around 5.8760 at worst and Eur/Czk towards the upper end of a 27.081-323 range.

US EQUITY OPEN: Risk friendly open with indices higher while defensive sectors lag
analysis_details:
MACRO SNAPSHOT: US equity futures are trading with a risk-on bias after Wednesday’s declines, which has been attributed to better than expected trade data out of China, notably exports which rose at a rate of 3.5% against expectations of an 11% decline; however, China's trade with the US continued to decline from January to April, the total value of China-US trade dropped 12.8% whilst China's imports from the US slid 3% and exports plunged 15.9%, and most of the export component is buoyed by medical shipments. Top US/China trade officials have also scheduled a call for next week, the first since January, and ahead of schedule (it is supposed to take place every six months); the news followed remarks from Trump yesterday that he'd be able to report in a week or two whether China's purchases were in line with its Phase 1 commitments. On that note, it was interesting that the PBOC fixed the USDCNY stronger for a second day, which has been taken as a positive by traders (this is definitely one to keep an eye on). There has been quite a bit of central bank activity to note: BOE left rates unchanged, but two policymakers called for more QE; the Norges Bank cut by 25bps rates to zero and sees no more cuts; while BCB delivered a larger than expected 75bps rate cut aftermarket on Wednesday. US Treasury yields are little changed after yesterday’s supply-induced steepening, the DXY is flat; remains above 100, gold and oil are higher.

SECTORS: All sectors open in positive territory, painting a risk friendly picture, with Energy outperforming amid firmer crude prices while Financials are also doing well after Ameriprise Financial (AMP) reported. The defensive Health Care, Staples, and Real Estate sectors are the laggards today, although still positive.

STOCK SPECIFICS: Costco Wholesale Corp. (COST) comparable SSS -4.7% in April. Liberty Global (LBTYA) and Telefonica (TEF) announced an agreement to merge its UK business to create a 50:50 JV. Zoom Video Communications (ZM) (Information Technology/Software) has reportedly been made accessible to teachers by the NYC education department after the DoE withdrew its ban on the app. Tesla (TSLA) has halted production at its Chinese factory. It is also worth noting CEO Musk will be appearing on the Joe Rogan podcast again; last time TSLA stock was hit after he smoked marijuana on the show. TSLA is also reportedly planning to restart production at its Fremont, California factory. Moderna (MRNA) is finalizing the protocol for its Phase 3 study of its COVID-19 vaccine MRNA-1273 and is expected to begin in early summer in 2020. Elsewhere, NIH Dr. Fauci highlighted the vaccine candidate, as well as Oxford University’s, accompanied by comments he expects the US to have a vaccine as soon as January. Ulta Beauty (ULTA) and Kohl’s (KSS) are to reopen select stores across the US.

EARNINGS: T-Mobile (TMUS) beat on EPS, missed on revenue, ARPU fared better than expected although net subscriber additions missed expectations. Raytheon Technologies (RTX) beat on both EPS and revenue. Paypal (PYPL) missed on EPS and revenue while it forecasts Q2 Adj. EPS growth of 15-20% and revenue growth of 13%. Hilton (HLT) beat on EPS and revenue; noted systemwide comparable RevPAR -22.6%. Lyft (LYFT) saw an EPS miss, although revenue was better than expected, it also announced it is planning to cut costs by USD 300mln by the end of the year.

JPM EARNINGS TRACKER: The bank notes that 66% of S&P500 companies have topped EPS estimates, with overall EPS growth improving since the start of the season (now -9% Y/Y); however, the bank says that earnings beats have not picked up, with the percentage of companies beating EPS estimates still at 10-year lows. In terms of sectors, Materials, Discretionary and Financials are showing double-digit negative EPS growth. Meanwhile, revenue growth is more or less flat.

HOW FAR CAN S&P 500 RALLY GO: We have noted several times that the downside in stocks has been backstopped by the Fed, while the upside is subject to risks around the pace and extent of normalisation of global economies, putting a lid on upside. From a valuation perspective, with forward earnings expected around USD 170 in FY 2021, and assuming a p/e of 17 or 18 suggests that the S&P 500 at 2,890-3,060 is consistent with the current narrative. Much has been made about how incoming economic data has been dire, and the S&P 500 may not be reflecting that, given that we are up around 30% from March lows, and US stocks have pared losses more quickly than other bear markets. Capital Economics thinks the gloom is now reflected in analysts’ expectations for earnings, noting that the latest estimates see EPS 40% lower in Q2 2020 than in Q4 2019, and while it is expected to recover as lockdowns are lifted, it is only seen returning to its pre-crisis levels by mid-2021. CapEco notes that sectors like IT, Communication and Health Care, which are likely to do relatively well out of the crisis, are heavily weighted in the index, while sectors like Energy and Financials, which have been hit really hard by the crisis, have a much smaller weight. “With all this in mind, the strength of the S&P 500 is not as irrational as it first appears,” CapEco writes, “and assuming that the virus outbreak is slowly brought under control in the coming months, and economies gradually begin to re-open in that time, we would not be surprised to see the index advance a bit further.” The consultancy notes that two key risks remain: “success in containing the virus could be reversed as economies reopen, and the consensus for maintaining current levels of policy support might break down. But assuming neither materialises, the rally in equities may have a bit further to run.

ANALYSIS: Weekly US jobless claims lower for the fifth straight week
analysis_details:
• Weekly initial jobless claims data printed 3.17mln, higher than the 3mln consensus; the prior was revised up slightly to 3.85mln -- the cumulative total since mid-March is now around 33.5mln. Continuing claims, meanwhile, jumped to 22.65mln, above the 19.91mln forecast, while the prior was revised higher -- that 22.65mln is around three times greater than the peak in the great recession.
  • Oxford Economics said that while initial claims continue to slowly recede from their peaks (this was the fifth straight week lower), they remain at painfully high levels - claims at 3.17mln are around 15 times the level of claims before the pandemic, OxEco notes, and the consultancy sees continuing claims numbers continuing to rise given it lags initial claims.
  • Others have noted that weekly claims are decaying at rate of around 15-18% per week, and if the current trajectory continues, claims will be sub-1mln in the second or third week of June.
  • "The April employment report to be released tomorrow will bring the damage done by the labor market into sharp relief," OxEco writes, "We look for 28mln in job losses and an unemployment rate of 17%. The April payroll data are a mid-month snapshot, however, and we expect further job losses will be reported in May."
  • NOTE: The April jobs report is due for release at 0830 ET/1330 BST on Friday 8th May; the consensus looks for -22mln and for the unemployment rate to spike to 16.0%; our full preview can be accessed here.

reaction_details: • In an immediate reaction, USD/TRY fell from around 7.2500 to a low of 7.1245 before stabilising sub-7.2000
analysis_details:
• NOTE: Turkey has expanded its definition of FX manipulation, and now banks trading financial markets (including FX and rates) who cause "misleading pricing" or trades that keep asset prices "abnormal or artificial" will be considered as manipulative.
  • Earlier, Turkey’s state media attributed the fall in the currency to fresh record lows as an orchestrated attack organised from London by foreign banks.
  • On Wednesday, Fed's Barkin effectively ruled-out swap lines with the CBRT, stating that facilities were already in place for central banks that provided "mutual trust" and that the Fed had swap lines with countries that have the highest credit standards and relationships with the US.
  • Some had also speculated that Turkey could impose ban on TRY shorting in a bid to avoid further currency free-fall

US PRE-MARKET THEMES: Equity futures trading higher, underpinned by China trade data
analysis_details:
MACRO SNAPSHOT: US equity futures are trading with a risk-on bias after Wednesday’s declines, which has been attributed to better than expected trade data out of China, notably exports which rose at a rate of 3.5% against expectations of an 11% decline; however, China's trade with the US continued to decline from January to April, the total value of China-US trade dropped 12.8% whilst China's imports from the US slid 3% and exports plunged 15.9%, and most of the export component is buoyed by medical shipments. Top US/China trade officials have also scheduled a call for next week, the first since January, and ahead of schedule (it is supposed to take place every six months); the news followed remarks from Trump yesterday that he'd be able to report in a week or two whether China's purchases were in line with its Phase 1 commitments. On that note, it was interesting that the PBOC fixed the USDCNY stronger for a second day, which has been taken as a positive by traders (this is definitely one to keep an eye on). There has been quite a bit of central bank activity to note: BOE left rates unchanged, but two policymakers called for more QE; the Norges Bank cut by 25bps rates to zero and sees no more cuts; while BCB delivered a larger than expected 75bps rate cut aftermarket on Wednesday. US Treasury yields are little changed after yesterday’s supply-induced steepening, the DXY is flat, gold and oil are higher.

JPM EARNINGS TRACKER: The bank notes that 66% of S&P500 companies have topped EPS estimates, with overall EPS growth improving since the start of the season (now -9% Y/Y); however, the bank says that earnings beats have not picked up, with the percentage of companies beating EPS estimates still at 10-year lows. In terms of sectors, Materials, Discretionary and Financials are showing double-digit negative EPS growth. Meanwhile, revenue growth is more or less flat.

HOW FAR CAN S&P 500 RALLY GO: We have noted several times that the downside in stocks has been backstopped by the Fed, while the upside is subject to risks around the pace and extent of normalisation of global economies, putting a lid on upside. From a valuation perspective, with forward earnings expected around USD 170 in FY 2021, and assuming a p/e of 17 or 18 suggests that the S&P 500 at 2,890-3,060 is consistent with the current narrative. Much has been made about how incoming economic data has been dire, and the S&P 500 may not be reflecting that, given that we are up around 30% from March lows, and US stocks have pared losses more quickly than other bear markets. Capital Economics thinks the gloom is now reflected in analysts’ expectations for earnings, noting that the latest estimates see EPS 40% lower in Q2 2020 than in Q4 2019, and while it is expected to recover as lockdowns are lifted, it is only seen returning to its pre-crisis levels by mid-2021. CapEco notes that sectors like IT, Communication and Health Care, which are likely to do relatively well out of the crisis, are heavily weighted in the index, while sectors like Energy and Financials, which have been hit really hard by the crisis, have a much smaller weight. “With all this in mind, the strength of the S&P 500 is not as irrational as it first appears,” CapEco writes, “and assuming that the virus outbreak is slowly brought under control in the coming months, and economies gradually begin to re-open in that time, we would not be surprised to see the index advance a bit further.” The consultancy notes that two key risks remain: “success in containing the virus could be reversed as economies reopen, and the consensus for maintaining current levels of policy support might break down. But assuming neither materialises, the rally in equities may have a bit further to run.”

JOBLESS CLAIMS COMING UP: Weekly initial jobless claims are seen lower for the fifth straight week at 3.0mln (range: 1.5mln to 9mln) in the week through 2/May, down from last week’s 3.8mln. Pantheon Macroeconomics is forecasting 3.2mln, basing its projection on hard data from Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and Arizona, and Google trends data on searches for "file for unemployment". "This approach to the data has been reasonably successful, but the history is very short and we can't be sure it will remain reliable," but with that said, it says that is forecast is consistent with the recent decay in claims (around 16%/week); "if that continues, claims will slip below one million per week by the third week of June. That would still be horrendous, bearing in mind that claims rose by only 665K in the worst single week after the crash of 2008, but it would be a world away from the nightmare of March and April." Full primer here. 

GET OUT OF CASH: UBS is telling its clients to get out of cash, and that waiting for absolute clarity before deploying cash will leave investors on the sidelines for a prolonged period. "Instead, those that have sat out the rally can build up long-term positions by combining an averaging-in strategy with put writing," the bank says, explaining that averaging into riskier assets enables investors to deploy capital while smoothing near-term bumps. "In addition, we think a selective approach in equities may help side-step some risks, with particular opportunity in select cyclicals, stable, and defensive stocks." UBS has also previously suggested moving into themes accelerated by COVID-19. "Many of the changes the coronavirus imposes on our everyday lives will hopefully be relatively short-lived. But the COVID-19 pandemic is likely to accelerate some longer-term trends, from e-commerce and fintech to automation, robotics, and genetic therapies."

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 7th May 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Sentiment is bolstered on trade updates; as such, European bourses and US futures are comfortably positive with US futures outperforming
  • US and China Trade Chiefs are said to plan a phone conversation as soon as next week on progress in implementing the trade deal
  • BoE left rates at 0.1% and maintained Gilt purchases, 2 dissenters on QE who wanted an extra GBP 100bln
  • Norges Bank defied consensus, cutting rates to 0.0% & announced further F-loans; but, do not envisage making further cuts
  • FX has seen the USD softer for much of the session, but the DXY has recently reclaimed the 100.00 handle and returned to positive territory
  • Saudi Aramco raises June Arab Light Official Selling Prices to Asia by USD 1.40 to USD -5.90
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US initial jobless claims, ECB's de Guindos, Fed's Harker
  • Earnings: Bristol-Myers Squibb, Danaher, Raytheon Technologies, Becton Dickinson

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

US Secretary of State Pompeo said he knows China did not act fast enough regarding the virus, while he added the US is in active talks with China regarding origins of the virus and reiterated he has seen evidence the virus came from a lab in China. (Newswires)

Kao Corp (4452 JT) and Kitasato University are reported to have succeeded in acquiring VHH antibody that has ability to suppress infection against the coronavirus and which should lead to drug development. (Newswires)

Tokyo has 23 new cases of COVID-19, according to Fuji TV. (Newswires)

Japanese Economy Minister says there is a chance that some areas will see the state of emergency lifted in some areas around May 14th. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed following the uninspiring handover from US where risk appetite was sapped by US-China tensions and a decline in the energy complex in which oil prices snapped a 5-day win streak, with the region also mulling over key releases from China including Caixin PMIs and the latest trade data. ASX 200 (-0.4%) was lower with the declines led by losses in energy names and gold miners due to the pressure in oil and after the precious metal gave up the USD 1700/oz status, while financials suffered with the largest bank CBA downbeat on speculation the Co. could have been impacted the worst from the coronavirus among the big 4 banks ahead of next week’s quarterly update. Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) initially underperformed on return from the 5-day Golden Week closure to take its first opportunity to digest the nationwide state of emergency extension in Japan, with index heavyweight Fast Retailing pressured pre-earnings and Softbank shared depressed after being sued by WeWork, although the losses in the index were retraced amid favourable currency moves. Hang Seng (-0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) were both cautious due to the increased US-China tensions and after Caixin Services and Composite PMI figures remained in contraction territory, although losses were stemmed by the Chinese trade data which showed a higher surplus and surprise expansion in exports despite imports remaining at a significant contraction. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower as prices tracked the recent downside in T-notes which had been weighed after a larger than expected US Treasury quarterly refunding announcement, although the losses were stemmed amid the BoJ’s presence in the market for nearly JPY 800bln of JGBs.

PBoC skipped open market operations and were net neutral on the day. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0931 vs. Exp. 7.1011 (Prev. 7.0690)

Chinese Trade Balance (CNY)(Apr) 318.2B vs. Exp. 39.5B (Prev. 139.4B). Chinese Exports (CNY)(Apr) Y/Y +8.2% vs. Exp. -14.1% (Prev. -3.5%) Chinese Imports (CNY)(Apr) Y/Y -10.2% vs. Exp. -12.2% (Prev. -2.4%)

Chinese Trade Balance (USD)(Apr) 45.34B vs. Exp. 6.35B (Prev. 19.9B, Rev. 19.93B). Chinese Exports (Apr) Y/Y 3.5% vs. Exp. -15.7% (Prev. -6.6%) Chinese Imports (Apr) Y/Y -14.2% vs. Exp. -11.2% (Prev. -0.9%, Rev. -1.0%)

Chinese Caixin Services PMI (Apr) 44.4 vs. Exp. 50.1 (Prev. 43.0). Chinese Caixin Composite PMI (Apr) 47.6 (Prev. 46.7)

EU Ambassador to China says breakthrough in EU-China negotiations is needed for a comprehensive investment agreement and that China needs to show much more ambition than it has demonstrated so far, while the ambassador added that an increase in US-China tensions is problematic to all sides. (Newswires)

US and China Trade Chiefs are said to plan a phone conversation as soon as next week; on progress in implementing the trade deal. (Newswires)

Chinese Commerce Ministry survey notes that foreign trade enterprises are still suffering from cancelled or delayed orders, logistics problems and difficulty in securing new order. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK BOE Bank Rate (May) 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.1%, unanimous decision; total purchases maintained at GBP 645bln (QE vote split 7-2, 2 preferring an increase of GBP 100bln) - existing monetary policy stance is appropriate, Stand ready to take further action as is necessary to support the economy. Economic forecasts can be found on the headline feed here. BoE Governor Bailey says we are not out of monetary policy tools and expects to continue to come up with appropriate responses. It remains appropriate that the bank continues with aggressive pace of asset purchases for the moment and will take stock of it.

Norges Bank cuts its Key Policy rate to 0% vs. Exp. 0.25%; decision unanimous; does not envisage making further policy rate cuts. Economic forecasts can be found on the headline feed here. Norges Bank Governor Olsen says it is possible to set negative rates but does not expect a reduction below 0%

ECB’s VP de Guindos says ECB monetary policy will continue to provide the necessary support so that liquidity gets through to the people of Europe and the real economy. But our response will be made more powerful if all policies reinforce each other. (Newswires)

EU Trade Commissioner Hogan dismissed call by US President Trump for American pharmaceutical companies to move production back to US, while he suggested it could be 2024 before EU economies fully recover. (RTE)

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump vetoed the Iran war powers resolution as expected according to the White House. There were also reports that US said it will move ahead with 120-day waiver to permit Iraq to import electricity from Iran, according to the State Department. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities hold onto gains [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.8%] amid a turnaround from the mostly negative APAC session, as sentiment is underpinned amid hopes US and China will iron out their differences in a call next week among top negotiators. That being said, it is difficult to pre-judge what the sentiment will be during the call, notably due to recent rhetoric emanating from the two nations, whilst US-China trade data does not bode well regarding the Phase One deal. Nonetheless, broad-based gains are seen across Europe, albeit the SMI (+0.3%) lags the region as its heavyweight healthcare names remain in modest negative territory, potentially on a risk-move as the sector lags. Energy and Materials meanwhile show slight outperformance as the oil and base metal complexes regain ground. The sector breakdown reflects a similar performance. In terms of individual movers – Telefonica (+0.2%) gave up most of its opening gains after rising some 3% on the back of a finalised deal with Liberty Global to merge UK assets worth just over GBP 31bln, set to reshape the UK telecom market. As such, Vodafone (-0.9%) and BT (-9.6%) see losses with the latter also exacerbated by dividend cancellation alongside its earnings. The Telefonica/Liberty deal is subject to regulatory approval.  AB InBev (+2.5%) holds onto gains post-earnings after the metrics were less severe than feared, but the group expects Q2 results to be materially worse than Q1. Air France (-4.1%) shares fell following detrimental earnings, with Q2 capacity seen down 95% and no expectations of a recovery to pre-crisis levels for several years. Meanwhile, Carnival (-2.0%) remains in the red after the Co’s Princess Cruises have extended halt in global operations through to the end of 2020 summer season, whilst Seabourn has extended its pause into October and November 2020.

Tesla (TSLA) - Have reportedly suspended car production at a Chinese factory

FX

NOK/GBP/SEK - Not the biggest G10 movers, but in focus and divergent after the Norges Bank delivered an unexpected 25 bp ease to pull the benchmark depo rate back down to zero and supplemented the additional stimulus with an extension of F-loans through to the end of August. Conversely, the BoE stuck to the script on conventional policy and QE, albeit with 2 dovish MPC dissenters calling for asset purchases to be upped by Gbp 100 bn. In response, the Norwegian Krona lost momentum through resistance at 11.0527 and before the big figure to retest 11.1500+ vs the Euro amidst further declines against the Swedish Crown that retains a hawkish hold Riksbank bid to compound its outperformance relative to a weaker single currency near 10.6000, while Cable rebounded from new 2 week lows to 1.2400+ at best and Eur/Gbp retreated towards 0.8700 after extending gains further beyond the 200 DMA.

AUD/NZD/CAD - Already boosted by encouraging export elements in Aussie and Chinese trade data overnight, the Antipodean Dollars have welcomed reports that officials from the US and China are planning to hold a call in relation to progress on the Phase 1 trade agreement next week given that relations between the 2 countries have become increasingly strained over the coronavirus. Aud/Usd is consolidating around 0.6450 and comfortably above a hefty option expiry at 0.6415 (1.2 bn), while Nzd/Usd has regained a firm foothold over 0.6000. Elsewhere, the Loonie has pared losses vs its US counterpart following a sharp slide to a fresh wtd trough circa 1.4173 on Wednesday by a full point in similar vein to crude prices after their midweek setback, eyeing Canadian Ivey PMIs on the eve of the big NA jobs showdown.

JPY/EUR/CHF - The return of Japanese participants from their Golden Week holidays has dampened demand for the Yen along with the aforementioned US-China trade talk news, with Usd/Jpy bouncing from 106.00 to 106.50 or so and the base of decent 1 bn+ expiry interest at the half round number, but not reaching those sitting between 106.65-75 in the same amount. In contrast, expiries may help the Euro deeper depreciation below 1.0800 after yet more worrying Eurozone economic releases, as 1.4 bn resides from 1.0780-75, though recoveries could also be thwarted by 2.3 bn at the 1.0800 strike or 1 bn just above (1.0805-10), especially if the DXY continues to make headway on the 100.000 handle having eclipsed its pre-month peak at 100.270.

EM - Most regional currencies are benefiting from a broad upturn in risk sentiment and oil returning to its recovery path, but for the Lira very little respite as Usd/Try rallies through the apex of Turkey’s 2018 crisis and remains in a seemingly endless uptrend approaching 7.2600. Elsewhere, CPI data looms for the Mxn and a 50 bp rate cut for the Czk, while the Brl will soon reflect on a bigger than expected ¾ point ease to a new 3% record low for the Selic.

Australian Trade Balance (AUD)(Mar) 10.6B vs. Exp. 6.8B (Prev. 4.4B). (Newswires) Australian Exports (Mar) M/M 15.0% (Prev. -5.0%) Australian Imports (Mar) M/M -4.0% (Prev. -4.0%)

New Zealand RBNZ 2yr Inflation Expectations 1.2% (Prev. 1.9%). (Newswires)

Brazilian Central Bank cut the Selic rate by 75bps to 3.00% vs. Exp. 50bps cut via unanimous decision, while it stated that April data so far shows economic contraction will be significantly larger than forecast at last COPOM meeting. Furthermore, it noted that for next meeting, depending on fiscal and economic outlook, the rate-setting committee is mulling a final cut of no more than 75bps. (Newswires)

FIXED

Bunds have regained some composure after delving beneath the 173.00 mark, but holding just above multi-week trend-line support at 172.83 and returning to 173.07, but their UK peer has retreated further into negative territory at 137.24 following no change in QE from the BoE even though the decision was not unanimous and some in the market were looking for Gbp 200 bn more vs +Gbp 100 bn advocated by 2 dissenters. However, US Treasuries appear to have calmed down and found a base after yesterday’s pronounced bear-steepening on supply issues as attention shifts to more anecdotal jobs data (Challenger and initial claims) ahead of NFP on Friday.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front month futures initially traded within a tight range relative to recent performance, with the benchmarks fluctuating between gains and losses in early trade. The contracts found a floor early-doors amid reports of a phone call next week between the top US and Chinese negotiators. Looking at the oil market itself, the forward Brent curve has tightened in recent days, reflecting an ease in the oil market glut – aided by production cuts and reviving demand as economies re-open from lockdown. On that front, Saudi Aramco raised its Arab Light OSPs to Asia following two consecutive cuts – signaling resurfacing demand in the region. That being said, Equinor’s CEO does not believe in a quick rebound in the oil market and added it could take until 2022 to see oil markets back normalise. The CEO said deeper cuts would improve the situation. WTI June now resides north of USD 25/bbl, and extends its intraday range (low USD 23.41/bbl), whilst Brent July sees itself printing fresh session highs, having rebounded from a low of USD 29.22/bbl. Elsewhere, spot gold saw some impetus from a softer Buck but remains below the USD 1700/oz mark (daily range USD 1685-1693.40/oz). Copper prices meanwhile remain underpinned by the rebound in the Chinese Trade Balance, coupled with upside seen in stocks supported by the US-China headlines.

Saudi Aramco raises June Arab Light Official Selling Prices to Asia by USD 1.40 to USD -5.90 vs. Oman/Dubai average (Prev. USD -7.30); NW Europe at USD -3.70 vs. ICE Brent (Prev. USD -10.25); US at USD +0.75 vs. ASCI (Prev. -0.75)

Iraq approved Mustafa Al-Kadhimi as its new PM although the vote for Iraq Oil Minister in parliament was postponed after no candidate was agreed on, according to lawmakers. (Newswires)

content:
