EQUITIES

European equities hold onto gains [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.8%] amid a turnaround from the mostly negative APAC session, as sentiment is underpinned amid hopes US and China will iron out their differences in a call next week among top negotiators. That being said, it is difficult to pre-judge what the sentiment will be during the call, notably due to recent rhetoric emanating from the two nations, whilst US-China trade data does not bode well regarding the Phase One deal. Nonetheless, broad-based gains are seen across Europe, albeit the SMI (+0.3%) lags the region as its heavyweight healthcare names remain in modest negative territory, potentially on a risk-move as the sector lags. Energy and Materials meanwhile show slight outperformance as the oil and base metal complexes regain ground. The sector breakdown reflects a similar performance. In terms of individual movers – Telefonica (+0.2%) gave up most of its opening gains after rising some 3% on the back of a finalised deal with Liberty Global to merge UK assets worth just over GBP 31bln, set to reshape the UK telecom market. As such, Vodafone (-0.9%) and BT (-9.6%) see losses with the latter also exacerbated by dividend cancellation alongside its earnings. The Telefonica/Liberty deal is subject to regulatory approval.  AB InBev (+2.5%) holds onto gains post-earnings after the metrics were less severe than feared, but the group expects Q2 results to be materially worse than Q1. Air France (-4.1%) shares fell following detrimental earnings, with Q2 capacity seen down 95% and no expectations of a recovery to pre-crisis levels for several years. Meanwhile, Carnival (-2.0%) remains in the red after the Co’s Princess Cruises have extended halt in global operations through to the end of 2020 summer season, whilst Seabourn has extended its pause into October and November 2020.

FX                                                                                     

NOK/GBP/SEK - Not the biggest G10 movers, but in focus and divergent after the Norges Bank delivered an unexpected 25 bp ease to pull the benchmark depo rate back down to zero and supplemented the additional stimulus with an extension of F-loans through to the end of August. Conversely, the BoE stuck to the script on conventional policy and QE, albeit with 2 dovish MPC dissenters calling for asset purchases to be upped by Gbp 100 bn. In response, the Norwegian Krona lost momentum through resistance at 11.0527 and before the big figure to retest 11.1500+ vs the Euro amidst further declines against the Swedish Crown that retains a hawkish hold Riksbank bid to compound its outperformance relative to a weaker single currency near 10.6000, while Cable rebounded from new 2 week lows to 1.2400+ at best and Eur/Gbp retreated towards 0.8700 after extending gains further beyond the 200 DMA.

AUD/NZD/CAD - Already boosted by encouraging export elements in Aussie and Chinese trade data overnight, the Antipodean Dollars have welcomed reports that officials from the US and China are planning to hold a call in relation to progress on the Phase 1 trade agreement next week given that relations between the 2 countries have become increasingly strained over the coronavirus. Aud/Usd is consolidating around 0.6450 and comfortably above a hefty option expiry at 0.6415 (1.2 bn), while Nzd/Usd has regained a firm foothold over 0.6000. Elsewhere, the Loonie has pared losses vs its US counterpart following a sharp slide to a fresh wtd trough circa 1.4173 on Wednesday by a full point in similar vein to crude prices after their midweek setback, eyeing Canadian Ivey PMIs on the eve of the big NA jobs showdown.

JPY/EUR/CHF - The return of Japanese participants from their Golden Week holidays has dampened demand for the Yen along with the aforementioned US-China trade talk news, with Usd/Jpy bouncing from 106.00 to 106.50 or so and the base of decent 1 bn+ expiry interest at the half round number, but not reaching those sitting between 106.65-75 in the same amount. In contrast, expiries may help the Euro deeper depreciation below 1.0800 after yet more worrying Eurozone economic releases, as 1.4 bn resides from 1.0780-75, though recoveries could also be thwarted by 2.3 bn at the 1.0800 strike or 1 bn just above (1.0805-10), especially if the DXY continues to make headway on the 100.000 handle having eclipsed its pre-month peak at 100.270.

EM - Most regional currencies are benefiting from a broad upturn in risk sentiment and oil returning to its recovery path, but for the Lira very little respite as Usd/Try rallies through the apex of Turkey’s 2018 crisis and remains in a seemingly endless uptrend approaching 7.2600. Elsewhere, CPI data looms for the Mxn and a 50 bp rate cut for the Czk, while the Brl will soon reflect on a bigger than expected ¾ point ease to a new 3% record low for the Selic.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds have regained some composure after delving beneath the 173.00 mark, but holding just above multi-week trend-line support at 172.83 and returning to 173.07, but their UK peer has retreated further into negative territory at 137.24 following no change in QE from the BoE even though the decision was not unanimous and some in the market were looking for Gbp 200 bn more vs +Gbp 100 bn advocated by 2 dissenters. However, US Treasuries appear to have calmed down and found a base after yesterday’s pronounced bear-steepening on supply issues as attention shifts to more anecdotal jobs data (Challenger and initial claims) ahead of NFP on Friday.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front month futures initially traded within a tight range relative to recent performance, with the benchmarks fluctuating between gains and losses in early trade. The contracts found a floor early-doors amid reports of a phone call next week between the top US and Chinese negotiators. Looking at the oil market itself, the forward Brent curve has tightened in recent days, reflecting an ease in the oil market glut – aided by production cuts and reviving demand as economies re-open from lockdown. On that front, Saudi Aramco raised its Arab Light OSPs to Asia following two consecutive cuts – signaling resurfacing demand in the region. That being said, Equinor’s CEO does not believe in a quick rebound in the oil market and added it could take until 2022 to see oil markets back normalise. The CEO said deeper cuts would improve the situation. WTI June now resides north of USD 25/bbl, and extends its intraday range (low USD 23.41/bbl), whilst Brent July sees itself printing fresh session highs, having rebounded from a low of USD 29.22/bbl. Elsewhere, spot gold saw some impetus from a softer Buck but remains below the USD 1700/oz mark (daily range USD 1685-1693.40/oz). Copper prices meanwhile remain underpinned by the rebound in the Chinese Trade Balance, coupled with upside seen in stocks supported by the US-China headlines.

PRIMER: US initial jobless claims due at 0830 ET/1330 BST; seen lower for a fifth straight week
analysis_details:
• Weekly initial jobless claims are seen lower for the fifth straight week at 3.0mln (range: 1.5mln to 9mln) in the week through 2/May, down from last week’s 3.8mln.
  • Pantheon Macroeconomics is forecasting 3.2mln, basing its projection on hard data from Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and Arizona, and Google trends data on searches for "file for unemployment". "This approach to the data has been reasonably successful, but the history is very short and we can't be sure it will remain reliable," but with that said, it says that is forecast is consistent with the recent decay in claims (around 16%/week); "if that continues, claims will slip below one million per week by the third week of June. That would still be horrendous, bearing in mind that claims rose by only 665K in the worst single week after the crash of 2008, but it would be a world away from the nightmare of March and April."
  • NOTE, this week’s initial jobless claims will not feature in the official BLS employment situation report, due tomorrow (the BLS survey period was two weeks ago).
  • Yesterday’s ADP private payrolls gauge showed 20.236mln jobs were shed from the US economy in April, close to the consensus view looking for -20mln; analysts had noted the uncertainty heading into the release, which had left expectations wide. It is difficult to read too much into the data, given much of the gloom had been signalled by other metrics in advance (primarily, the more timely weekly initial jobless claims data), and as such, the data merely confirms what the market was already discounting (hence the muted reaction in asset prices).
  • In terms of the breakdown, Capital Economics noted that ADP job losses came predominantly in the services sector, though the health care sector was hit as well. CapEco says that the report is a bit light on details of any potential methodological problems this month: “The ADP counts anyone on the active payroll rather than just people who were paid during the month, which is the official non-farm payroll definition,” and with many folks temporarily laid off, “that could have created a discrepancy, with those people still on the active payroll, but not counted in the official non-farm payroll figures and also qualifying as unemployed in the other official household survey.” The takeaway, Capital Economics says, is that the official BLS print on Friday might look even worse than the ADP report implies. Currently, the consensus looks for -21.9mln (though this may be revised ahead of the release), and the jobless rate is seen jumping to 16.0% from 4.4%. The narrative on Friday may be focusing around the ‘largest monthly fall ever’ line.

  • Economic activity is expected to pick up as containment measures are eased, but it will likely take time for output and employment to return to the levels prevailing before the pandemic.

  • Alternative 2, the downturn in the Norwegian economy becomes deeper and longer than in the baseline scenario.

subject: ANALYSIS: US-Chinese top trade negotiators to speak next week
content:
OVERVIEW: Sources said the two sides will conduct a phone call among top trade chiefs regarding the progress in implementing the Phase One trade deal. USTR Lighthizer and his Chinese counterpart Liu He will partake in the call, and this will be the first time the two sides hold discussions since January. The trade deal calls for the two negotiators to convene every six months – this call will be takin place ahead of schedule.

SENTIMENT: It is difficult to pre-judge what the sentiment will be during the call, notably due to recent rhetoric emanating from the two nations – initially sparked by the US’ complaints regarding China’s reporting and handling on the coronavirus. However, participants note that some discussions are better than none.

RECENT RHETORIC:

  • US: US President Trump recently threatened to terminate the deal with China should it not adhere to its commitments under the Phase One deal. Furthermore, the US President floated the idea of tariffs as a potential punishment for China’s handling of the pandemic. Trump has blamed China for playing down the scale and risks of the virus – a move believed to be correlated to the US Presidential Election.
  • CHINA: China has blamed US officials for attempting to shift their “poor handling” of the pandemic. Analysts via SCMP noted that China can retaliate by dumping its US Treasury holdings whilst imposing tariffs of their own, albeit Chinese officials yesterday noted that tariffs should not be used as a weapon. Meanwhile, underlying soured sentiment remains on the Hong Kong front – Chinese Foreign Ministry said it opposes US interference on China's affairs with Hong Kong.

TRADE DATA: The Chinese trade data released overnight for April printed a substantially larger than the expected surplus in CNY and USD terms as the nation resurfaces from lockdown. However, China's trade with the US continued to decline from January to April, the total value of China-US trade dropped 12.8% whilst China's imports from the US slid 3% and exports plunged 15.9%, according to Global Times.

Melrose (MRO LN) –Group sales -20% YY due to the pandemic. Co. refrains from providing guidance. Co. notes that cutting or delaying both Capex and long-term restructuring are reducing costs. (Newswires)

Metso (METSO FH) - Q1 EPS EUR 0.35 vs. Prev. EUR 0.43. Adj. EBITDA EUR 91mln vs. Prev. EUR 105mln. Revenue EUR 832.0mln vs. Prev. EUR 836.0mln. (Newswires) 

Novartis (NOVN SW) - Co. priced its treatment for hard-to-treat lung cancer at USD 17,950 for a 28-day supply. (Newswires)

Puma (PUM GY) – Q1 EBIT -50% to EUR 71.2mln vs. Prev. EUR 142.5mln. Net earnings and net EPS -62% YY. Operating expenses EUR 553mln vs Prev. EUR 511mln. Q1 has been heavily impacted by the pandemic. Co. has secured EUR 900mln revolving credit facility. (Newswires)

Rio Tinto (RIO LN) - Co. is to spend ~USD 1bln over 5yrs on climate projects and R&D. (Newswires)  

Rolls-Royce (RR/ LN) – Co. can now deliver up to GBP 1bln in savings this year. Working with supply chain to reduce direct procurement as well as placing over 4k employees on furlough. Currently expects to deliver around 250 widebody engines in 2020 vs. Prev. view of 450. (Newswires)

Snam (SRG IM) – Q1 net profit +5% YY to EUR 298mln. Total revenue +4.6% to EUR 691mln. EBITDA +4.6% to EUR 567mln. Net financial debt EUR 12.256bln vs. Prev. EUR 11.923mln. (Newswires)

Telefonica (TEF SM)/BT (BT/LN)/ Vodafone (VOD LN) – Telefonica and Liberty Global (LBTYA) have reached a deal to merger UK assets. The companies will have equal ownership of O2 and Virgin Media. O2 global valuation stand at GBP 12.7bln and Virgin Media at GBP 18.7bln – for a total of GBP 31.4bln. JV is expected to deliver synergies of GBP 6.2bln by the fifth FY after closing the deal. The deal is subject to regulatory approvals. (Newswires) Telefonica will receive GBP 5.5bln in cash to help reduce its debt, according to sources. (FT)

Telefonica (TEF SM) – Q1 net profit EUR 40mln vs. Prev. EUR 926mln. Revenue EUR 11.37bln vs. Prev. EUR 11.98bln. Q1 OIBDA EUR 3.76bln vs. Prev. EUR 4.26bln. Co. has withdrawn guidance. (Newswires)

UK Banks - UK FPC judges that the usable buffers of capital built up by banks are more than sufficient to absorb losses under the BoE MPR scenario. (Newswires)

HISCOX (HSX LN) UPGRADED TO EQUAL WEIGHT FROM UNDERWEIGHT AT BARCLAYS

Daily European Equity Opening News
content:
7 May 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0200CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real-time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed following the uninspiring handover from US where risk appetite was sapped by US-China tensions and a decline in the energy complex in which oil prices snapped a 5-day win streak, with the region also mulling over key releases from China including Caixin PMIs and the latest trade data. ASX 200 (-0.4%) was lower with the declines led by losses in energy names and gold miners due to the pressure in oil and after the precious metal gave up the USD 1700/oz status, while financials suffered with the largest bank CBA downbeat on speculation the Co. could have been impacted the worst from the coronavirus among the big 4 banks ahead of next week’s quarterly update. Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) initially underperformed on return from the 5-day Golden Week closure to take its first opportunity to digest the nationwide state of emergency extension in Japan, with index heavyweight Fast Retailing pressured pre-earnings and Softbank shared depressed after being sued by WeWork, although the losses in the index were retraced amid favourable currency moves. Hang Seng (-0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) were both cautious due to the increased US-China tensions and after Caixin Services and Composite PMI figures remained in contraction territory, although losses were stemmed by the Chinese trade data which showed a higher surplus and surprise expansion in exports despite imports remaining at a significant contraction.

FTSE 100

Carnival (CCL LN) – Co’s Princess Cruises have extended halt in global operations through to the end of 2020 summer season. Seabourn has extended its pause on operations into October and November 2020. (Newswires)

Rolls-Royce (RR/ LN) – UK Housing Minister Jenrick said the gov’t wants to support the aviation sectors and remain in contact with the Co. (Newswires)

UK Banks - Fitch has warned that some of the UK's largest banks are on track to report up to GBP 25bln of loan losses this year amid rising default from borrowers. (Times)

BROKER MOVES

ANGLO AMERICAN (AAL LN) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT CREDIT SUISSE

BEAZLEY GROUP (BEZ LN) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JPMORGAN CHASE

BURBERRY (BRBY LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD A HSBC

GLENCORE (GLEN LN) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OUTPERFORM AT CREDIT SUISSE

TUI (TUI LN) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERWEIGHT FROM EQUAL WEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

DAX

Deutsche Telekom (DTE GY) - T-Mobile US Inc (TMUS) reported Q1 20 (USD): EPS 1.10 (exp. 1.02), Revenue 11.1bln (exp. 11.38bln); does not provided FY guidance but will present refined outlook in Q2. Services revenue 8.7bln (exp. 9.5bln). Churn 3.52% in Q1 (exp. 1.35%). ARPU 45.80 (exp. 44.80). Net subscriber additions 777k (exp. 1.1mln) NOTE: Deutsche Telekom owns 42.1% of T-Mobile; shares in T-Mobile rose 0.7% after-market.

Wirecard (WDI GY) – Deka Investment are reportedly calling for the CEO Braun to be dismissed; remarking he is ‘primarily responsible for the massive loss in confidence’. (FT) Deka have a 1.4% stake in the Co.

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Brenntag (BNR GY) – Q1: EPS EUR 0.74/shr, sales EUR 3.206bln, -0.3%; EBITDA EUR 262.3mln, +8.4%. FY19 dividend of EUR 1.25/shr will be distributed in full. Will update forecasts once 2020 business performance can be more accurately determined given COVID-19. (Newswires)

Evonik (EVK GY) – Q1 Adj. EBITDA EUR 513mln vs. Exp. EUR 511mln. Revenue EUR 3.24bln vs. Prev. EUR 3.29bln. Co. cuts FY adj. EBITDA guidance to EUR 1.7-2.1bln vs. Prev. EUR 2.0-2.3bln. and cuts revenue guidance to EUR 11.5-13.0bln vs. Prev. ~EUR 13.1bln. (Newswires)

HeidelbergCement (HEI GY) – Q1: group revenue EUR 3.930bln vs. Prev. EUR 4.238bln, current operation result EUR 59mln vs. Prev. EUR 56mln. Measures to deal with COVID-19 are highly effective, will weather the crisis well; EUR 1bln in cash savings from plan initiated in February. Progressive dividend suspended & cut dividend proposal to EUR 0.60/shr vs. Prev. EUR 2.20/shr. (Newswires)

Metro AG (B4B GY) – Q1 adj net EUR -116mln vs. Prev. EUR -58mln. Adj. EBITDA EUR 133mln vs. Prev. EUR 130mln. Revenue EUR 6.01bln vs. Prev. EUR 5.90bln. LFL sales +2.3% YY. Co. notes that every month in the current lockdown situation will cause sales declines on 2ppts YY. (Newswires)

Osram Licht (OSR GY) – Q2 net EUR -39mln vs. Prev. EUR -91mln. Adj. EBITDA EUR 96mln vs. Prev. EUR 70mln. Revenue EUR 821mln vs. Prev. EUR 862mln. Co. withdraws guidance. (Newswires)

Sixt (SIX2 GY) – Co. has singed a syndicated loan agreement with a consortium of banks which consists of EUR 1.5bln with a term of up to two years. (Newswires)

Zalando (ZAL GY) - Co. guides FY revenue +10-20% and Adj EBITDA between EUR 100-200mln vs. Prev. reported EUR 224.9mln. Capex guided between EUR 230-280mln. Co. expects to grow profitably. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

UNIPER (UN01 GY) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM NEUTRAL AT JPMORGAN CHASE

CAC

Airbus (AIR FP) – Have informed Air France (AF FP) that some of the A350 jets scheduled for delivery this year will not be ready until 2021. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Air France-KLM (AF FP) – Q1 net EUR -1.8bln vs. Prev. EUR -326mln. Adj. operating EUR -815mln vs. Prev. EUR -286mln. Revenue GBP 5.02bln vs. Prev. EUR 5.94bln. Co. sees Q2 capacity -95% and Q3 -80%. Co. does not expected to recover to pre-crisis level before several years. (Newswires)

Natixis (KN FP) – Q1 net EUR -204mln vs. Prev. EUR +767mln. Adj. operating EUR -26mln vs. Prev. EUR +330mln. Revenue EUR 1.75bln vs. Prev. EUR 1.96bln. Co. cuts its FY20/21 CET1 ratio target to 10.2% vs. Prev. 11.2%. (Newswires)

Nexans (NEX FP) – Q1 revenue EUR 1.57bln vs. Prev. EUR 166bln. Organic revenue -0.1% YY. Co. decided not to propose a dividend. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

ESSILORLUXOTTICA (EL FP) DOWNGRADED TO SELL FROM HOLD AT SOCGEN

GETLINK (GET FP) DOWNGRADED TO SELL FROM HOLD AT SOCGEN

PAN EUROPE

AB InBev (ABI BB) – Q1 Adj. EBITDA -13.7% vs. Exp. 14.7%. Revenue USD 11bln vs. Exp. USD 10.76bln. Q1 total volumes 119.7mln hL vs. Prev. 131.7mln hL. Q1 total volumes -9.3%, beer volumes -10.5% and non-beer -0.2%. Profit attributable to equity holders USD -845mln vs. Prev. USD +395mln YY. China revenue 45.4% - which resulted in a volume decline of 46.5%. Co. expects Q2 2020 results to be materially worse than Q1. Separately, Co’s Budweiser (1876 HK) reported Q1 net USD -6mln vs. Prev. USD +259mln. Adj. EBITDA USD 171mln vs. Prev. USD 558mln. Revenue USD 956mln vs. Prev. USD 1.6bln. Total volumes -42.3% to 12.8mln. (Newswires)

ArcelorMittal (MT NA) – Q1 revenue USD 14.84bln vs. Exp. USD 15.58bln. EBITDA USD 967mln vs. Exp. USD 890.6mln. Co. has suspended dividend payments and pulled forecasts for steel demand. Sees steel shipments below 2019 levels. (Newswire)

Atlantia (ATL IM) – Italian motorway network traffic -72.6% last week. (Newswires)

DSM (DSM NA) – Q1 adj. EBITDA EUR 423mln vs. Exp. EUR 413mln. Revenue EUR 2.29bln vs. Exp. EUR 2.3bln. Co. suspends outlook. (Newswires)

Enel (ENEL IM) – Q1 net EUR 1.28bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.23bln. Adj. EBITDA EUR 4.74bln vs. Exp. EUR 4.55bln. Revenue EUR 20.0bln vs. Prev. EUR 20.9bln. Co. affirms FY targets. CEO said there is no risk to dividend payment. (Newswires)

Telefonica (TEF SM)/BT (BT/LN)/ Vodafone (VOD LN) – Telefonica and Liberty Global (LBTYA) are said to have reached a deal to merger UK assets in a deal worth over GBP 24bln, sources said. Under the deal, Telefonica will receive GBP 5.5bln in cash to help reduce its debt. The companies will have equal ownership of O2 and Virgn Media. (FT) The deal was confirmed in which the O2 global valuation stand at GBP 12.7bln and Virgin Media at GBP 18.7bln – for a total of GBP 31.4bln. JV is expected to deliver synergies of GBP 6.2bln by the fifth FY after closing the deal. The deal is subject to regulatory approvals. Telefonica has withdrawn guidance. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

BBVA (BBVA SM) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JPMORGAN CHASE

RANDSTAD (RAND NA) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM SELL AT GOLDMAN SACHS

SMI                 

Roche (ROG SW) – New data at ASCO20 virtual scientific programme reflects Genentechs commitment to an acceleration in cancer care progress. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

Equinor (EQNR NO) – Q1 adj. net USD 560mln vs. Exp. USD 680mln. Adj. operating USD 2.05bln vs. Exp. USD 2.04bln. Organic Capex USD 8.5bln vs. Prev. view of USD 8.5bln. Revenue USD 15.1bln vs. Prev. USD 16.5bln. Equity production 2.23mln BOEPD vs. Exp. 2.208mln BOEPD. Co. suspends FY20 production guidance. (Newswire)

Metso (METSO FH) – Co. has arranged USD 290mln in new funding. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

ADECCO (ADEN SW) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM SELL AT GOLDMAN SACHS

AKERBP (AKERBP NO) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT BERENBERG

OUTOKUMPU (OUT1V FH) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT DEUTSCHE BANK

PANDORA (PNDORA DC) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT SEB ENSKILDA

SCHIBSTED (SCHB NO) DOWNGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT SEB ENSKILDA

US

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -0.7% at 2848, NDX +0.6% at 8985, DJIA -0.9% at 23,665. SECTORS: Information Technology +0.7%, Discretionary +0.3%, Health Care -1%, Communications -1.1%, Staples -1.1%, Industrials -1.4%, Materials -1.8%, Real Estate -1.8%, Financials -2.3%, Energy -2.6%, Utilities -3.5%

subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 7th May 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

·        Asian equities traded mixed following the uninspiring handover from US where risk appetite was sapped by US-China tensions and a decline in energy prices

·        Chinese Caixin Services and Composite PMI figures remained in contraction territory, trade data showed a larger surplus than forecast and a jump in exports

·        US President Trump said he will be able to report on whether or not China is abiding to the Phase One trade deal in a week or two

·        The DXY held above 100.00 amid the risk averse tone and following the weakness in its major counterparts

·        Looking ahead, highlights include BoE rate decision, minutes & MPR, German industrial output, EZ construction PMI, Norges Bank rate decision, US initial jobless claims, ECB's de Guindos, Norge's Olsen, BoE's Bailey, Fed's Harker, supply from France and Spain

·        Earnings: ArcelorMittal, Puma, Ab InBev, Continental, Osram Licht, Evonik, Uniper, BT, IAG, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Danaher, Raytheon Technologies, Becton Dickinson

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

US President Trump said the administration will be naming new members on the coronavirus task force by Monday, while he wants to terminate healthcare coverage under Obamacare and replace it with a new, cheaper system that covers pre-existing conditions. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said he knows China did not act fast enough regarding the virus, while he added the US is in active talks with China regarding origins of the virus and reiterated he has seen evidence the virus came from a lab in China. (Newswires)

US CDC reported total coronavirus cases as of previous day at 1600EDT increased to 1,193,813 (Prev. 1,171,510), while total death toll was at 70,802 (Prev. 68,279). (Newswires)

UK COVID-19 Death toll rose 2.2% to 30,076 from 29,427(Prev. +2.4%). Reports have noted that the UK is set to remove its “stay home” slogan over the weekend as the nation prepares to ease lockdown measures. (Telegraph)

Kao Corp (4452 JT) and Kitasato University are reported to have succeeded in acquiring VHH antibody that has ability to suppress infection against the coronavirus and which should lead to drug development. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed following the uninspiring handover from US where risk appetite was sapped by US-China tensions and a decline in the energy complex in which oil prices snapped a 5-day win streak, with the region also mulling over key releases from China including Caixin PMIs and the latest trade data. ASX 200 (-0.4%) was lower with the declines led by losses in energy names and gold miners due to the pressure in oil and after the precious metal gave up the USD 1700/oz status, while financials suffered with the largest bank CBA downbeat on speculation the Co. could have been impacted the worst from the coronavirus among the big 4 banks ahead of next week’s quarterly update. Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) initially underperformed on return from the 5-day Golden Week closure to take its first opportunity to digest the nationwide state of emergency extension in Japan, with index heavyweight Fast Retailing pressured pre-earnings and Softbank shared depressed after being sued by WeWork, although the losses in the index were retraced amid favourable currency moves. Hang Seng (-0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) were both cautious due to the increased US-China tensions and after Caixin Services and Composite PMI figures remained in contraction territory, although losses were stemmed by the Chinese trade data which showed a higher surplus and surprise expansion in exports despite imports remaining at a significant contraction. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower as prices tracked the recent downside in T-notes which had been weighed after a larger than expected US Treasury quarterly refunding announcement, although the losses were stemmed amid the BoJ’s presence in the market for nearly JPY 800bln of JGBs.

PBoC skipped open market operations and were net neutral on the day. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0931 vs. Exp. 7.1011 (Prev. 7.0690)

Chinese Trade Balance (CNY)(Apr) 318.2B vs. Exp. 39.5B (Prev. 139.4B). Chinese Exports (CNY)(Apr) Y/Y +8.2% vs. Exp. -14.1% (Prev. -3.5%) Chinese Imports (CNY)(Apr) Y/Y -10.2% vs. Exp. -12.2% (Prev. -2.4%)

Chinese Trade Balance (USD)(Apr) 45.34B vs. Exp. 6.35B (Prev. 19.9B, Rev. 19.93B). Chinese Exports (Apr) Y/Y 3.5% vs. Exp. -15.7% (Prev. -6.6%) Chinese Imports (Apr) Y/Y -14.2% vs. Exp. -11.2% (Prev. -0.9%, Rev. -1.0%)

Chinese Caixin Services PMI (Apr) 44.4 vs. Exp. 50.1 (Prev. 43.0). Chinese Caixin Composite PMI (Apr) 47.6 (Prev. 46.7)

US President Trump said China may or may not keep the trade deal and that he will be able to report on whether or not China is abiding to the Phase One trade deal in one week or two, while he added that he believes US death toll figures but does not believe China's death toll. (Newswires)

EU Ambassador to China says breakthrough in EU-China negotiations is needed for a comprehensive investment agreement and that China needs to show much more ambition than it has demonstrated so far, while the ambassador added that an increase in US-China tensions is problematic to all sides. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Four Governing Council members of the ECB are reportedly adamant that the ECB should not respond directly to the GCC ruling on PSPP, with a majority opposing a response; due to potential ramifications and opening the opportunity for further national court pressure in the future. Some members suggest the Bundesbank could respond instead; adding, would not be surprised if Chancellor Merkel intervened to resolve the situation. (FT)

EU Trade Commissioner Hogan dismissed call by US President Trump for American pharmaceutical companies to move production back to US, while he suggested it could be 2024 before EU economies fully recover. (RTE)

FX

The DXY held above the 100.00 level amid the risk averse tone and following the weakness in its major counterparts, in particular, EUR/USD which fell below the 1.0800 handle. Sources noted that the ECB is said to be keen to avoid a direct role in the German constitutional court legal case and are also reportedly divided on who will respond to the German courts request, with recent bleak Eurozone economic forecasts also providing the currency with no favours. GBP/USD was lacklustre and extended on yesterday’s losses despite PM Johnson hinting they could begin easing lockdown restrictions from Monday, while focus turns to the BoE’s policy announcement which is scheduled for the earlier time of 0700BST. USD/JPY attempted to nurse losses after rebounding from support at 106.00, while antipodeans were initially choppy although were later marginally spurred after Australian trade figures showed a wider than expected surplus and a 15% M/M jump in exports and following the mostly better than expected China trade data.

Australian Trade Balance (AUD)(Mar) 10.6B vs. Exp. 6.8B (Prev. 4.4B). (Newswires) Australian Exports (Mar) M/M 15.0% (Prev. -5.0%) Australian Imports (Mar) M/M -4.0% (Prev. -4.0%)

New Zealand RBNZ 2yr Inflation Expectations 1.2% (Prev. 1.9%). (Newswires)

Brazilian Central Bank cut the Selic rate by 75bps to 3.00% vs. Exp. 50bps cut via unanimous decision, while it stated that April data so far shows economic contraction will be significantly larger than forecast at last COPOM meeting. Furthermore, it noted that for next meeting, depending on fiscal and economic outlook, the rate-setting committee is mulling a final cut of no more than 75bps. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were rangebound with WTI crude futures choppy around the USD 24/bbl following the prior day’s losses in which oil prices snapped a 5-day win streak as focus shifted back to the demand and storage concerns. Nonetheless, WTI is off its lows with only a mild recovery seen overnight after the better than expected Chinese trade data. Gold languished beneath the USD 1700/oz level with the precious metal hampered as the DXY held above the 100.00 level, while copper ultimately benefitted from the encouraging China trade data but with upside limited by the varied risk appetite.

Iraq approved Mustafa Al-Kadhimi as its new PM although the vote for Iraq Oil Minister in parliament was postponed after no candidate was agreed on, according to lawmakers. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump vetoed the Iran war powers resolution as expected according to the White House. There were also reports that US said it will move ahead with 120-day waiver to permit Iraq to import electricity from Iran, according to the State Department. (Newswires)

US

The TPLEX saw pronounced bear steepening after the US Treasury quarterly refunding announcement came in above many expectations, particularly in the longer-dated tenors, in addition to further chunky corporate issuance volumes. Analysts also suggested that the lack of 4-year or 6-year announcement in the headlines seems to suggest the play of curve steepening will likely continue as the Treasury extends the average maturity of its outstanding debt. TD’s analysts noted, “USTs will need more setup into the auctions next week, which should steepen the curve and underperform OIS and swaps (i.e., tighter swap spreads).” The raised issuance naturally draws attention onto the Fed, and whether it will be able to continue tapering purchases as it has been if the market lets yields rise further. TD believes the Fed will ultimately rise to the challenge given that growth is unlikely to rebound, “But the Fed’s “pain point” may be higher rates with better Treasury market functioning and easier financial conditions.” By settlement today, 2s and 5s little changed at 0.18% and 0.38%, respectively, with 10s +5bps at 0.71%, and 30s +8bps at 1.41%. US T-note futures (M0) settled 10 ticks lower at 138-17.

Fed's Kaplan (voter, dove) said the reopening of Texas will be very phased and gradual, while he reiterated that he expects 25-30% annual decline in US GDP in Q2 and unemployment to peak at 20%. Kaplan added that the Fed will need to run very accommodative monetary policy for an extended period of time and noted that lending programmes are to credit-worthy companies and highly leveraged companies concerned about insolvency won't be able to access them. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia-Pac trades cautious as region digests key China data
content:
Asia equity markets trade subdued following the uninspiring handover from US where risk appetite was sapped by weak ADP jobs data, US-China tensions and a decline in the energy complex in which oil prices snapped a 5-day win streak. Furthermore, the region is mulling over key releases from China including Caixin PMIs and the latest trade data. ASX 200 (-0.3%) is lower with the declines led by losses in energy names and gold miners due to the pressure in oil and after the precious metal gave up the USD 1700/oz status, while financials are also weaker with the largest bank CBA downbeat as reports speculate the Co. could have been impacted the worst from the coronavirus among the big 4 banks ahead of next week’s quarterly update. Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) initially underperformed on return from the 5-day Golden Week closure to take its first opportunity to digest the nationwide state of emergency extension in Japan, with index heavyweight Fast Retailing pressured pre-earnings and Softbank is depressed after being sued by WeWork, although the losses in the index were retraced amid favourable currency moves. Hang Seng (-0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) are both cautious due to the increased US-China tensions and after Caixin Services and Composite PMI figures remained in contraction territory, although losses were stemmed by the Chinese trade data which showed a higher surplus and surprise expansion in exports although imports remained at a significant contraction.

In FX markets, the DXY is firmer and remains above the 100.00 level amid the risk averse tone and following the weakness in its major counterparts, in particular, EUR/USD which fell below the 1.0800 handle as the German court ruling on ECB purchases continued to reverberate in the single currency. Sources have noted that the ECB is said to be keen to avoid a direct role in the German constitutional court legal case and are also reportedly divided on who will respond to the German courts request, with recent bleak Eurozone economic forecasts also providing the currency with no favours. GBP/USD is lacklustre and extended on yesterday’s losses despite PM Johnson hinting they could begin easing lockdown restrictions from Monday, while focus turns to the BoE’s policy announcement which is scheduled for the earlier time of 0700BST. Elsewhere, USD/JPY attempts to nurse losses after rebounding from support at 106.00, while antipodeans were choppy but found some mild support after Australia trade figures showed a wider than expected surplus and a 15% M/M jump in exports and following the mostly better than expected China trade data.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower despite the cautious risk tone as prices track the recent downside in T-notes which had been pressured after a larger than expected US Treasury quarterly refunding announcement, although the losses in JGBs are stemmed amid the BoJ’s presence in the market for nearly JPY 800bln of JGBs.

Huawei - US Department of Commerce is said to be near to signing off on a new rule that would permit US companies to work with China’s Huawei on setting standards for next generation 5G networks, according to sources. (Newswires) 

Trade

US President Trump said China may or may not keep the trade deal and that he will be able to report on whether or not China is abiding to the Phase One trade deal in one week or two, while he added that he believes US death toll figures but does not believe China's death toll. (Newswires)

SCMP citing analysts suggested that China may move to reduce its holdings of US Treasury securities in the coming months in response to a resurgence in trade tensions, whilst it may consider imposing tariffs of its own or reducing its agricultural purchases. (SCMP)

Other News

China are reportedly considering dropping their numerical GDP growth target for 2020. In other news, China Politburo said COVID prevention and control still faces uncertainty, while it will extend VAT cuts for small firms and aims to complete CNY 1trln of local govt bonds by end-May, Furthermore, the Cabinet will create tools to support banks to issue unsecured loans. (Newswires)

Chinese Premier Li stated that China will intensify policy support to keep employment stable and safeguard people’s livelihoods. (Newswires)

PBoC general administration department and research team reiterated that China will keep conventional monetary policy as long as possible. In other news, PBoC Shanghai unit said it is to tolerate more non-performing loans in manufacturing. (Newswires)

PBoC said it had conducted a total of CNY 100bln in MLF operations and CNY 27.2bln in SLF operations, but didn’t provide info on PSL operations. (Newswires)

PBoC and Finance Ministry are said to be debating differing ideas on funding the economic recovery post-coronavirus. (Newswires)

Reports note rumour if US seeks renumeration for coronavirus damages, it could escalate to war with China. (SCMP)
